stories.title: Companies Want Remote Workers in All States but 1

stories.text:
I’m sure most have have of this trope (https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=4627373) and that’s kinda how I feel right now.

A lot of jobs I see at my YoE are senior level and use terms like “domain expert” that I just can’t read and say “yeah this is me”. I just can’t imagine performing in roles like this. I’m not an expert at anything, besides maybe figuring out how to figure out things I want to do. At the same time, I don’t feel much like a junior or anything. I have very cursory understanding of a lot of stuff, but a large swath of it is useless because I don’t have any experience back it up.

What are the typical moves for someone in this sort of situation.
stories.title: Ask HN: X Years of 1 year of experience. What to do?

stories.text: As part of a conference I've been invited to present in, I've been asked to talk about integrating security into agile application development and I want to be able to talk about common ways in which security had failed in Agile development. Apart from the most obvious problems of not integrating security into DevOps or not testing the dependencies, do you guys know of any case studies of companies that have made large mistakes (security-wise) when building applications in an agile manner?
stories.title: Ask HN: What are the common ways in which security fails in agile development?

stories.text:
My partner is looking for jobs in the space. She wants to work at a company that’s not just a boring corpo slog.

Any recommendations would be great!
